Model of two-step enzymatic plant pathway for synthesis of <math alttext="I A A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> from tryptophan Auxins are plant hormones that coordinate several aspects of root growth and development. Indole-<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-acetic acid (<math alttext="I A A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is an auxin that is usually synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan (Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>). Gene <math alttext="T r p T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> encodes an enzyme that converts tryptophan to indole-<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-pyruvic acid (<math alttext="I 3 P A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I3PA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), which is then converted to <math alttext="I A A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by an enzyme encoded by the gene <math alttext="Y U C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Circle ONE arrow that represents transcription on the template pathway. Identify the molecule that would be absent if enzyme <math alttext="Y U C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>YUC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is nonfunctional.

Gene <math alttext="T r p T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> encodes an enzyme that converts tryptophan to indole-<math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>-pyruvic acid (<math alttext="I 3 P A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I3PA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), which is then converted to <math alttext="I A A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by an enzyme encoded by the gene <math alttext="Y U C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Y</mi><mi>U</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. (b) Predict how the deletion of one base pair in the fourth codon of the coding region of gene <math alttext="T r p T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>r</mi><mi>p</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>T</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> would most likely affect the production of <math alttext="I A A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your prediction.

(c) Explain one feedback mechanism by which a cell could prevent production of too much <math alttext="I A A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> without limiting <math alttext="I 3 P A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I3PA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production.

(d) Rhizobacteria are a group of bacteria that live in nodules on plant roots. Rhizobacteria can produce <math alttext="I A A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and convert atmospheric nitrogen into forms that can be used by plants. Plants release carbon-containing molecules into the nodules. Based on this information, identify the most likely ecological relationship between plants and rhizobacteria. Describe ONE advantage to the bacteria of producing <math alttext="I A A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) A researcher removed a plant nodule and identified several “cheater” rhizobacteria that do not produce <math alttext="I A A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IAA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> or fix nitrogen. Describe the evolutionary advantage of being a bacterial cheater in a population composed predominantly of non-cheater bacteria. Plants can adjust the amount of carbon-containing molecules released into nodules in response to the amount of nitrogen fixed in the nodule. Predict the change in the bacterial population that would cause the plant to reduce the amount of carbon-containing molecules provided to the nodule.
